title: Let the Trans-Atlantic Trading Begin
summary: Seven key principles for building a bilateral bloc based on mutual prosperity and shared values.. With Brexit done, the U.K. and U.S. have an opportunity to create a model bilateral trade agreement, and with it revitalize their special relationship. Both President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Boris Johnson have expressed interest in such a deal. The president tweeted in December that Mr. Johnson's election created the possibility of a "massive new trade deal," and the prime minister's office released a statement days later saying the two leaders hoped to strike an "ambitious free trade agreement."

title: Uproar Over Essays Turns MLK's Dream Inside Out
summary: The University of Montana judged contest submissions on content instead of the writers' race. Big mistake.. The University of Montana asked students, staff and community members to participate in an essay contest on the legacy of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. When the school released the results last month, Montana students and race activists across the country accused university officials of racism and disrespect. That's because all four winners were white. Turns out some would rather the school had honored King by judging entrants on the color of their skin rather than the content of their submissions.

title: Drain the Swamp of Ugly Architecture
summary: Trump plans a welcome executive order requiring federal buildings to be built in the classical style.. 'Making Federal Buildings Beautiful Again," a new executive order planned by the Trump administration, would thrill lifelong amateur architects George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. These Founders-who designed Mount Vernon, Monticello and the Virginia State Capitol-wanted the new nation's public buildings to embody its ideals of self-governance, rooted in Greek democracy and Roman republicanism. They would surely applaud President Trump's proposed order to build new federal buildings in the classical style.

title: Uber Steps on the Earnings Pedal
summary: Accelerating profitability will be a challenge, but ride-hailing giant has little choice. Say this much for the management team at Uber Technologies Inc. : They got the message.

title: Notable & Quotable: Acquitted
summary: 'We've been going through this now for over three years. It was evil. It was corrupt. It was dirty cops. It was leakers and liars.'. President Trump, speaking to supporters in the White House, Feb. 6:

title: The Democrats' Unserious Week
summary: The fiasco in Iowa, the foolishness at the State of the Union-do they realize how bad they look?. Democrats, when they're feeling alarmed or mischievous, will often say that Ronald Reagan would not recognize the current Republican Party. I usually respond that John F. Kennedy would not recognize the current Democratic Party, and would never succeed in it.

title: The 90-Day Prescription Isn't for Everyone
summary: Pharmacies and insurers push it over physicians' warnings.. 'Why were you given that much medication in the first place?" I often find myself wondering that as I treat patients with a history of suicide attempts who have intentionally overdosed on their 90-day supply of medication.

title: 'Adventures of a Jazz Age Lawyer' Review: The Man Who Fought Pirates
summary: Songwriters and other popular artists saw their interests threatened by technology and thievery. In Nathan Burkan they found a ferocious champion.. It was front-page news in the Hackensack, N.J., evening paper. The Aug. 18, 1905, headline read: "Couchois Is Again Arrested." Garrett J. Couchois had been recently hauled into court on charges of selling copies of a Tin Pan Alley tune. Now, a week later, it happened again.

title: God Goes Missing in 'Little Women'
summary: The Oscar contender is distinctive, but leaves out a critical part of the story.. This weekend director Greta Gerwig's adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women" is up for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture. It is the seventh feature film to be made from Alcott's book and perhaps the most distinctive. Unfortunately, the latest film leaves out an important theme from the original text: faith.

title: The State of the Democrats
summary: The split between progressives and moderates could sink the party in November.. Donald Trump visited Congress this week to declare the state of the union "stronger than ever before." Speaker Nancy Pelosi concluded the evening by highlighting the state of the Democratic Party: Intensely-perhaps fatally-divided.

title: NYSE Owner Abandons Potential eBay Deal
summary: Investors had pushed back against move to acquire e-commerce company. The parent company of the New York Stock Exchange abandoned its pursuit of eBay Inc. in a dramatic reversal just days after its interest in a deal became public, triggering a backlash from investors.

title: In Praise of Modern Architecture
summary: A draft executive order mandating classical architecture as the official government style would result in watered-down design.. The news that an executive order, entitled "Making Federal Buildings Beautiful Again," has been drafted mandating that "the classical architectural style shall be the preferred and default style" for federal buildings, as reported in the Architectural Record earlier this week, has caused consternation among architects. On Wednesday, the American Institute of Architects promptly issued a statement denouncing it, and followed that up on Thursday with a letter to President Trump. As is always the case when draft reports are leaked to the public, one does not know if this is a trial balloon, put up to gauge public support, or a hostile leak, meant to kill an initiative in the cradle.

title: T-Mobile Projects More Customer Gains in 2020
summary: Judge's verdict on merger with Sprint hovers over projections. T-Mobile US Inc. maintained a positive view of its prospects in the wireless marketplace as a potentially game-changing court verdict loomed over the company.

title: AB InBev CFO Says He's Ready to Close Chapter and Do Something New
summary: Felipe Dutra is leaving after the brewer's Asian business went public in September, which came after a previous IPO attempt was called off. Felipe Dutra, Anheuser-Busch InBev SA's departing finance chief, said he is leaving the world's biggest brewer to seek a new challenge after 15 years in the role.

title: Aurora Cannabis Chief Executive To Depart Amid Layoffs
summary: The company also named two new independent directors to the board, bringing the total number of board members to 10. Aurora Cannabis Inc. said Thursday that Chief Executive Terry Booth is retiring, amid hundreds of layoffs and a restructuring plan aimed at cutting costs.

title: Warner Music Group Files for IPO
summary: Move comes as music industry enjoys streaming-fueled resurgence. Access Industries Inc.'s Warner Music Group Corp. filed documents to sell shares to the public amid a streaming-fueled resurgence in the music industry.

title: New York Philharmonic Begins Premiering Work of 19 Female Composers
summary: Largest women-only commissioning initiative is in celebration of the centennial of women's suffrage. Nina C. Young recalled a visit by her mother in September when a brochure from the New York Philharmonic arrived in the mail. "Oh it's you! Next to Haydn and Mozart."

title: New York City Wants More Basement Apartments to Tackle Housing Crunch
summary: Mayor de Blasio announces plan during his State of the City address. New York City will change zoning rules to ease the process of converting basements, garages and backyard sheds into apartments, as part of a push to create more affordable housing, Mayor Bill de Blasio said at his annual State of the City address Thursday.

title: Progressives Push Taxes Targeting Wealthy to Plug New York's Budget Deficit
summary: A surcharge on stock buybacks, a special assessment on pieds-à-terre, and new charges on luxury yachts and private jets are among the suggestions. ALBANY, N. Y.-A surcharge on stock buybacks. A special assessment on pieds-à-terre. New charges on luxury yachts and private jets.

title: Bank Supervisor Sees Weaknesses in Compliance With Due Diligence Rule
summary: Some banks don't have adequate policies or procedures in place, a senior official from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said. WASHINGTON-Some banks have failed to put in place adequate policies to comply with a rule that requires them to identify the owners of corporate accounts, a senior regulator said Thursday.

title: Meredith Shares Rally as Publishing Giant Digests Time Inc.
summary: Publisher of People and Real Simple has been cutting the frequency of some titles and shuttering others. Investors drove shares of Meredith Corp. up 15% after the largest U.S. magazine publisher posted a jump in profit for the December quarter, suggesting it is getting its arms around its acquisition of Time Inc.

title: Tesla's Stock Boom: It's OK to Miss Out
summary: While the car maker's prospects have improved, there is no justification for the recent tear in the stock. There are several good reasons to think Tesla Inc. should be more valuable today than it was six months ago. But there aren't any that justify its shares more than tripling in price since then, let alone its value rising and then falling by the equivalent of Ford Motor 's capitalization in a day.

title: CBD Producer GenCanna Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Company said cost overruns for new hemp processing plant and drop in cannabidiol prices contributed to chapter 11 filing. GenCanna Global USA Inc., a large Kentucky producer of cannabidiol, or CBD, oil and other hemp products, has filed for bankruptcy following cost overruns and construction delays at a new processing center and a fire last year at its existing facility.

title: Huawei Sues Verizon Over Patents
summary: Lawsuits argue that Verizon should pay the Chinese company for using telecom technologies it patented. HONG KONG-Huawei Technologies Co. is suing U.S. carrier Verizon Communications Inc. to demand it pay fees for the use of a dozen patents in its networks, escalating a long-simmering dispute between the two telecom giants.

title: Risky Corporate Debt to Take Center Stage in 2020 Stress Tests
summary: The Federal Reserve will test the strength of the largest U.S. banks by subjecting them to a hypothetical recession. The Federal Reserve will test the strength of the largest U.S. banks by subjecting them to a hypothetical recession in which credit markets seize up and private-equity investments take a hit.

title: Child Allegedly Sexually Assaulted on U.S. Embassy Grounds in India
summary: A 25-year-old son of a local employee was arrested and remains in custody, police said. NEW DELHI-The 5-year-old daughter of a local employee of the U.S. Embassy in India was allegedly sexually assaulted in a residential facility for Indian staff on the embassy grounds, according to local police.

title: Homeland Security Steps Up Feud as It Bars New Yorkers From Global Entry
summary: Federal authorities have long said New York and other states' so-called sanctuary policies make immigration enforcement harder. The Department of Homeland Security's move to bar New Yorkers from enrolling in expedited-travel programs including Global Entry signals a new front in the Trump administration's feud with states and cities over immigration enforcement.

title: N.J. Jury Orders J&J to Pay $750 Million in Punitive Damages
summary: Judge plans to reduce punitive award to $186.5 million in first trial in which CEO Gorsky testified in court. A New Jersey state jury on Thursday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $750 million in punitive damages to four people who said their use of the company's talcum powders caused a rare cancer, the latest legal loss for the health-care giant.

title: DXC Hires GE Executive as CIO
summary: Chris Drumgoole is a veteran of GE's shift to the cloud. DXC Technology Co. has appointed Chris Drumgoole, chief information officer of General Electric Co. and a veteran of the company's cloud efforts, as its new technology chief.

title: ICE Agent Shoots Man in New York City, Officials Say
summary: Shooting in Brooklyn occurred as agents attempted to arrest a suspected illegal immigrant. A U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent shot a man and two agents were injured during the arrest of a suspected illegal immigrant in Brooklyn on Thursday, amid rising tensions between the federal agency and New York City over its so-called sanctuary policy.

title: Beijing Faults U.S. Stance on Coronavirus
summary: Government singles outs U.S. for criticism over travel restrictions, plays down American aid efforts. SHANGHAI-Beijing has publicly criticized the U.S. for days over its response to the dangerous coronavirus, despite working in the background with American authorities and accepting U.S. aid to contain its spread in China.

title: FCC Moves to Free Up Spectrum for Potential Cellphone Service
summary: Agency would pay a group of satellite companies billions of dollars to upend their operations. The Federal Communications Commission will pay a group of satellite companies billions of dollars to upend their operations so a valuable swath of the radio spectrum can be used for cellphone service, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai said.

title: 'Battle for Hong Kong': A People Rises Up
summary: This 'Frontline' documentary captures the anger of the Hong Kong protests in vivid detail.. In the opening scene of the brutally eloquent "Battle for Hong Kong" (Tuesday, 10 p.m., PBS) crowds of pro-democracy demonstrators surround the car of an off-duty policeman and succeed in beating him bloody, armed though he is. The time is early October 2019, in the midst of massive antigovernment protests in Hong Kong. Dazed and furious as he examines his wounds, the officer waves his gun and phones in for backup, saying he's been beaten up, as the taunting crowd moves away. A male voice is heard daring him to put the gun away and fight him. It's clear throughout this documentary largely built on remarkably graphic footage of crowds battling the police that the rage of an officer of the law is as nothing compared with the seething fury that drives these protesters.

title: Lawmakers See Benefits in Facial Recognition, Despite Concerns
summary: Customs official touts technology's efficiency and accuracy; some worry about bias, surveillance threat. WASHINGTON-Several House lawmakers expressed reservations Thursday about increasing use of facial recognition to identify people entering the country, but their views didn't sway U.S. customs officials and other House members who said the technology promises to make the nation safer.

title: 'Horse Girl' Review: A Mind Running at a Gallop
summary: Alison Brie stars as a seemingly normal woman with frightful delusions.. There are certain aspects of "Horse Girl" (Friday, Netflix) that are incomprehensible, none more so than its capacity to sustain interest, notwithstanding early indications, all of them borne out, of a shaky dramatic enterprise. Nevertheless, this story of Sarah (a distinguished performance by Alison Brie)-a seemingly normal young woman at the mercy of frightful delusions-quickly proves seductive. And so it remains for the greater part of this film (written by Jeff Baena and Ms. Brie, and directed by Mr. Baena) until it doesn't.

title: Kimmeridge Energy Hires Veteran Wellington Management Analyst Mark Viviano
summary: The hiring is a sign of the pressure traditional money managers are under to become more active. Kimmeridge Energy Management Co. LLC has hired longtime Wellington Management Co. energy analyst and portfolio manager Mark Viviano to lead public-equity investing and activism in the sector.

title: U.S. to Seek Trade Pact With Kenya
summary: Plans for trade talks come as President Trump met Kenyan counterpart at White House. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said it would launch negotiations toward a possible trade agreement with Kenya in what would be the first such pact with a sub-Saharan African nation.

title: Interior Expands Approved Uses on Former National Monument Land in Utah
summary: New rules for activity that can take place on the land permit timber harvesting and off-road vehicle use in some areas. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration finalized plans Thursday for what activities can take place on two drastically downsized national monuments in Utah, an action that environmentalists say will open the lands to mining, drilling and timber harvesting.

title: Casper Sleep Shares Rise 13% in First Day of Trading
summary: Casper has a valuation of about $575 million based on where shares opened Thursday. Shares of Casper Sleep Inc. closed about 13% higher on their first day of trading Thursday, a day after the mattress-seller priced its IPO at the lower end of its expected price range.

title: Estée Lauder Cuts Profit Goals as Coronavirus Slows Travel Sales
summary: Virus outbreak to hurt sales from airport shoppers and in China, two key growth areas. Estée Lauder Cos. cut profit expectations, saying China's viral outbreak will mar sales to travelers and Chinese consumers, which have been major growth drivers for the beauty giant.

title: Google to Triple Its Canadian Workforce
summary: Alphabet unit plans to bolster employment at its Montreal gaming studio, cloud computing offices. Google is planning to more than triple its Canadian workforce over three years, as the technology giant steps up hiring at its Stadia gaming studio as well as for cloud computing and artificial intelligence projects.

title: Congress Shifts to Campaign Mode After Impeachment
summary: Lawmakers show little sign of mending partisan divide as election looms and must-pass legislation is largely finished. WASHINGTON-A divided Congress will return to its legislative business following the Senate vote to acquit President Trump in his impeachment trial, but the narrow chance to accomplish much legislatively during an election year suggests its focus will shift to the 2020 fight for control of each chamber.

title: Photos: Key Moments in the Tensions Between Trump and Pelosi
summary: Resume Subscription. The relationship between President Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) has become increasingly strained, with insults and snubs related to the Democrats' impeachment efforts overshadowing any efforts for bipartisan cooperation.

title: 'The Lodge' Review: Chilly and Vacant
summary: A weekend of winter fun turns grisly in a horror tale by Severin Fiala and Veronika Franz.. The most horrible thing about "The Lodge," a horror flick set mostly in a snowbound vacation house, is that it's no fun. Scary movies about screw-loose characters doing awful things to one another are supposed to be perversely enjoyable; we like to be terrified when we can control the terror, if only by closing our eyes. This film, directed by Severin Fiala and Veronika Franz-they did the deadly effective "Goodnight Mommy"-deploys its elements dutifully, then plays them out at the speed of permafrost melting beneath a December sun. The premise is serviceable: Who's crazy here, and to what degree? Yet the payoff is ponderous. At one point an annunciatory blast from an organ announces nothing in particular, but at least relieves the tedium.

title: 'Birds of Prey': Harley Redux, With Joy
summary: Margot Robbie returns as a free-spirited Harley Quinn with an all-female crew.. So the big news in "Birds of Prey: (And the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)" is that Harley (Margot Robbie) broke up with the Joker. Good riddance to bad rubbish. And good riddance to the worse rubbish of her appearance with him more than three years ago in "Suicide Squad." That famously dreary production, based on characters from DC Comics, was a misfortune for all concerned-but especially for Ms. Robbie, since her fans were anticipating a full-scale breakthrough role.

title: In Flurry of Violence, Car Rams Into Israeli Soldiers and Two Palestinians Die in Clashes
summary: Violent attacks are gaining momentum a week after President Trump unveiled his proposals to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. TEL AVIV-A Palestinian driver rammed a car into a group of Israeli soldiers in Jerusalem, injuring 14 people, and clashes in the West Bank left two Palestinians dead, one of them a security officer, a week after President Trump unveiled his peace plan for the region.

title: Tyson Feels Weight of Lower Poultry Prices
summary: Meat processor's quarterly chicken profit sinks by over half, but China demand is expected to rise. A bounty of unusually heavy birds is weighing on Tyson Foods Inc.'s chicken business.

title: Canadian Court Is Urged to Rule Facebook Broke Privacy Laws
summary: Watchdog presses for changes in how social-media company collects, discloses users' personal data. OTTAWA-Canada's main privacy watchdog on Thursday asked a court to hold hearings on Facebook Inc.'s privacy practices and force the company to change the way it handles users' personal information.

title: China Tariff Relief Boosts Stock Market
summary: Stocks close higher, including in Asia, where markets have been most hit by concerns over the coronavirus. U.S. stocks rose Thursday after China said it would cut in half tariffs on $75 billion of U.S. imports, signaling it would follow through with parts of a recently signed trade agreement.

summary: Schoolgirl savagery is at the center of Erica Schmidt's inventive adaptation of Shakespeare's play.. New York

title: Shale Gas Swamps Asia, Pushing LNG Prices to Record Lows
summary: The idling of factories in China due to coronavirus quarantines is weighing on prices already pressured by other bearish factors. Liquefied natural gas is fetching the lowest price on record in Asia, a troubling sign for U.S. energy producers who have relied on overseas shipments of shale gas to buoy the sagging domestic market.

title: Russia Blocks OPEC Response to Coronavirus
summary: The rejection of the Saudi plan is a setback for the OPEC-Moscow alliance. VIENNA-Russia has rejected a Saudi-led effort to deepen OPEC's oil-production cuts in response to the deadly coronavirus in China, cartel delegates said.

title: Notorious Hit Man for Escobar's Medellín Cartel Dies at 57
summary: Jhon Jairo Velásquez, known as 'Popeye,' said he had killed hundreds of people in shootings and bombings. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-By his own account, Jhon Jairo Velásquez killed hundreds of people in the name of Pablo Escobar's Medellín cartel, as the crime group flooded the U.S. with cocaine in the 1980s and '90s and battled the Colombian state and its American allies.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended February 1
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: FAA Flags Warning-Light Problem with 737 MAX
summary: Boeing says fixing latest glitch shouldn't delay work to return aircraft to service. LONDON- Boeing Co. needs to resolve a new software glitch as part of its work to get the 737 MAX recertified for flight, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Juul Raises $700 Million From Investors
summary: Funding round follows writedown by Altria, revised partnership. Juul Labs Inc. has raised more than $700 million in convertible debt to fund its operations, according to people familiar with the matter, as the e-cigarette maker confronts increasing financial and regulatory pressures.

title: Fall of WorldCom's Bernard Ebbers Sent Chilling Message to CEOs
summary: Ebbers's conviction and imprisonment demonstrated the risk of pleading ignorance of wrongdoing.

title: 5 Uncrowded, Unpretentious Ski Resorts
summary: From the Colorado Rockies to British Columbia, these mob-free mountain escapes are bucking the mega-pass trend. LAST FEBRUARY, at Silverton Mountain in Colorado's San Juan Mountains, a friend and I spent a gleeful day riding up an old-school double chairlift and skiing down fluffy powder runs. We had the deep snow nearly to ourselves and rarely crossed tracks. In fact, away from the lift, we hardly saw any fellow skiers at all. The simple reason: Silverton limits daily ticket sales to about 80 guests.

title: 'Fiasco': From Italian Glass to Iowa's Botched Election
summary: An old Latin term for bottle mysteriously took on a meaning of disaster before it jumped to politics-and to this week's caucus snafu. What to call the utter disarray that dogged the 2020 Iowa Democratic caucus contest? The presidential primary season kicked off on Monday with embarrassingly long delays and uncertainty in the reporting of results from Iowa, which the state Democratic Party blamed on a buggy app that was intended to streamline the tallying of votes and delegates in the complex caucus system.

title: Diverse Goldman Confronts Humpty Dumpty
summary: The deeper problem with Goldman Sachs's refusal to take companies public "unless there's at least one diverse board candidate" is its Orwellian redefinition of "diverse.". Regarding your editorial "Goldman Gets Half Woke" (Jan. 25): The deeper problem with Goldman Sachs 's refusal to take companies public "unless there's at least one diverse board candidate" is its Orwellian redefinition of "diverse."

title: There's No Republican Case for Sen. Warren
summary: Each of Sen. Warren's proposals has the government requiring private companies to accept Washington's directive.. Regarding Sheila Bair's "The Republican Case for Elizabeth Warren" (op-ed, Jan. 31): I am left wondering if the Sen. Warren who Ms. Bair knows is the same person those of us know from watching, listening to and reading the Warren campaign events, position papers and media reports.

title: Trump's Tariffs Sure Aren't Working for Us
summary: Our carpentry (and the carpentries around us) lost between 30%-35% of revenue since 2017 because of huge price increases in raw material due to the new tariffs.. Regarding Elizabeth Mulgrew's "Tariffs Must Work Because We're Doing Well" (Letters, Jan. 29): Our carpentry (and the carpentries around us) lost between 30%-35% of revenue since 2017 because of huge price increases in raw material due to the new tariffs. The tariff program is not working here in Florida.

title: San Jose's Severe Housing Shortage Is Easy to Fathom
summary: Local government has made it virtually impossible to build new housing.. While it's true that the tech boom over the past 50 years in Santa Clara County has increased demand for housing by creating lots of great new jobs, the constraint on supply-which is why there's a crisis-is 100% due to local governments' restrictive zoning and overzealous regulatory schemes ("San Jose Pursues Tech Giant, Carefully," Page One, Jan. 29). Simply put, local government has made it virtually impossible to build new housing, causing prices to soar. Blaming demand for supply's failure is upside down.

title: Shares of NYSE Owner Slide on Fresh eBay Deal Jitters
summary: Intercontinental Exchange's stock dropped 5.5%. Shares of Intercontinental Exchange Inc. dropped 5.5% on Thursday after it failed to tamp down investors' jitters that it could pursue a costly acquisition of eBay Inc.

title: Where Five Democratic Front-Runners Head After the Campaign Trail
summary: An overview of the real-estate portfolios of Pete Buttigieg, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Joe Biden and Michael Bloomberg. The front-runners for the democratic presidential nomination may disagree on health care and tuition-free college, but they share one thing in common: a good nose for real estate.

title: Partisanship, Uncertainty Constrained Obama Russia Response, Report Finds
summary: Report details prolonged interagency disagreements among senior officials who were caught off guard by Russia's 2016 election interference operations. WASHINGTON-The Obama administration struggled to develop a coordinated and effective response to Russian interference in the 2016 election, constrained in its options by partisanship in Washington and a lack of timely definitive attribution that Moscow was responsible, according to a bipartisan Senate report released Thursday.

title: Airlines' China Cutbacks Amid Coronavirus Outbreak Squeeze Freight Capacity
summary: Cargo companies fear bottlenecks for expedited shipments once factories resume production. A steep reduction in airline services to China in response to the coronavirus outbreak is slashing trans-Pacific capacity for high-value, expedited goods that move as airfreight, and setting the stage for potential outbound cargo bottlenecks once Chinese factories resume production.

title: Are Ski Resorts Getting Too Crowded? Yes and No
summary: Part of the new Ikon mega-pass ski network, Vermont's Stratton Mountain welcomes throngs on weekends. A rusty, hopeful skier braves the 'high-speed mobs'. "DONNN WORRY-we're not scary," slurred an obviously plastered man as my husband and I climbed into the crowded, cacophonous shuttle to Black Bear Lodge in Stratton Mountain, Vt. Despite our greeter's joie de vivre, I quailed at the prospect facing me: a bracing January ski weekend.

title: Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac to Stop Accepting Libor Mortgages

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said they will stop accepting adjustable-rate mortgages tied to the London interbank offered rate by the end of 2020, a boost for the Federal Reserve's preferred replacement to the troubled short-term interest benchmark.

title: Harvey Weinstein Attorneys Paving Way for Possible Appeal
summary: Defense is highlighting prosecutors' failure to turn over key evidence and judicial rulings. title: The Sooner Fiat Chrysler Can Merge With Peugeot the Better

The choice is ironic for Jeep-maker Fiat Chrysler , which has been on a journey of continuous change over the past decade-in the process making more money for investors than any other big vehicle maker except Tesla.

summary: Ram and Jeep brands continue to do well, though company sees softening in U.S. market overall. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV earned bragging rights among Detroit auto makers as its North American profit margin outpaced that of its rivals for the fourth quarter and all of 2019.

title: U.S. Plans to Renew Sanctions Waiver on Iraq's Imports of Iranian Power
summary: Iraq relies heavily on Iranian natural gas but the U.S. is pushing for the country to wean itself off that energy source. BAGHDAD-The U.S. has made preliminary plans to renew a waiver allowing Iraq to import natural gas and electricity from Iran without risking sanctions, U.S. and Iraqi officials said, as Washington and Baghdad move to ease tensions after diplomatic ties nearly unraveled last month.

title: How China Built Two Coronavirus Hospitals in Just Over a Week
summary: Resume Subscription. China on Thursday completed the second of two new hospitals in Wuhan, the city at the heart of the coronavirus outbreak, in a matter of days to help combat the fast-spreading virus.

title: Remixing Native American Art
summary: Artist Jeffrey Gibson sees his own work as part of an innovative tradition. Jeffrey Gibson first spotted "The Dying Indian"-a bronze statue of a Native American man on horseback, by the American sculptor Charles Cary Rumsey-while he was leaving the Brooklyn Museum. Mr. Gibson, an artist of Choctaw and Cherokee descent, was struck not just by the sculpture's suggestion of a vanishing Native American culture but by its placement behind the building, near the parking lot. "It's such a cliché of museums to have one of these sculptures"-a Native American scene like Rumsey's, made by a non-Native artist around the turn of the last century-"and to not know what to do with it," Mr. Gibson said. "The first priority for me was getting 'The Dying Indian' inside the museum."

title: Treasury to Sell $198 Billion in Debt
summary: Next week's auctions by the U.S. Treasury Department will include 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. The Treasury Department will auction $198 billion in securities next week, comprising $84 billion in new debt and $114 billion in previously sold debt. summary: Boon for troubled German bank comes as Europe's lenders continue to grapple with low interest rates. Deutsche Bank AG got a vote of confidence in its turnaround plan Thursday as U.S. investor Capital Group Cos. disclosed it has built a stake in the bank.

title: Another American Hiring Surge
summary: The NFIB January report says the jobs boom is still going strong.. The great American jobs boom continued at small companies in January, with more hiring and rising wages. title: For the Roguish Trader in Your Life
summary: Nick Leeson, the man who brought down Barings, will show you the ropes. Taking the notion of "if you can't do, teach" to new heights, an infamous rogue trader seems to have entered the for-profit education business.

title: Kellogg Lowers Expectations for 2020
summary: Cereal and snack maker is investing in promising brands to boost sales; shares fall. Kellogg Co. provided a sober outlook for profit and sales this year, as the food maker invests more in snacks and works to rejuvenate struggling cereal brands.

title: When Plagues Derive From the Animal Kingdom
summary: Coronavirus is just the latest of many deadly diseases to cross over to human beings from other species. Earlier this week, the still-rising death toll in mainland China from the coronavirus surpassed the 349 fatalities recorded during the 2003 SARS epidemic. Although both viruses are believed to have originated in bats, they don't behave in the same way. SARS spread slowly, but its mortality rate was 9.6%, compared with about 2% for the swift-moving coronavirus.

title: Cutting Your Home Down to Size
summary: Readers reflect on a recent Counting House column about downsizing. In the Counting House column on Jan. 22 , Beth DeCarbo shared how to decide what's worth keeping when downsizing. Readers had a lot to say on the matter. Here are excerpts from some of their letters.

title: Twitter Snaps to It
summary: Unlike Snapchat parent, Twitter's mixed fourth-quarter results had the benefit of low expectations. Twitter isn't quite taking flight again, but its fourth-quarter results Thursday were enough to give the battered social network some much-needed lift.

title: German Nativists Drive Wedge in Merkel's Conservative Party
summary: Aborted alliance between populists and conservative archenemies in East Germany provokes backlash. title: Cancel Culture Comes to France
summary: French universities are embracing an American trend by censoring speakers and suppressing controversial views. Last April, Alain Finkielkraut-one of France's leading public intellectuals and a member of the prestigious Academie Française-was invited by a student group to give a lecture on "modernity, heritage and progress" at the elite Paris university Sciences Po. Mr. Finkielkraut, who has forcefully defended Western traditions and criticized cultural relativism, drew the wrath of far-left activists who denounced him as "profoundly reactionary," a "racist and misogynist" whose ideas "put our own existence in danger."

title: Where Are All the Women CEOs?
summary: The traditional stepping stones to the chief executive position are jobs responsible for the bottom line-such as head of division-and those roles are still overwhelmingly filled by men. title: Eiderdown Is Nature's Perfect Duvet
summary: The microstructure of their feathers allows eider ducks to stay warm in frigid Arctic waters.. This is the coldest time of year in the Northern Hemisphere. I only step outside attired in a thick cocoon of thermal insulation, including sweater, coat, hat and gloves. But even on the chilliest days, the ducks on the nearby river are squabbling and foraging in the shallows. That's because they benefit from the warmest natural material known: down feathers. The ingenuity of down comes from the fact that it almost isn't there. Its minimalist structure is startlingly effective.

title: Mnuchin Says U.S. 2020 Growth to Be Less Than 3% Due to Boeing
summary: Treasury Secretary says officials are closely monitoring the coronavirus, but said they hadn't yet seen major effect on supply chains. 's 737 MAX.

summary: Shares jumped about 7% in reaction to the earnings news and higher dividend prospects. UniCredit SpA, Italy's largest bank, posted better-than-expected results for the fourth quarter of 2019, although it swung to a net loss for the period largely due to one-off costs and provisions.

title: Scientists Link China Virus to Intersection of Humans and Wildlife
summary: More studies pinpoint bats as likely origin of deadly coronavirus. Scientists tracking how the deadly new coronavirus leapt from animals to humans said the likely source of the infection is bats, underscoring the health risks associated with humans' increasing push into the habitats of wild animals.

title: Trump's Second-Term Agenda Still on the Drawing Board
summary: The president rarely discusses what he would do if he wins another term, but his advisers have begun to sketch out ideas. title: A Skin-Care Line That Channels the Mediterranean Diet
summary: Irene Forte Skincare is made entirely in Italy with many edible ingredients, inspired by the family's organic farm in Sicily. Hospitality is part of Irene Forte's lineage. Her grandfather Lord Charles Forte had an empire of more than 800 hotels, and since 1996 Irene's father, Rocco, and his sister Olga have run their own hotel group, Rocco Forte Hotels. Irene Forte, 31, is the group's wellness director, overseeing the hotels' spas. Over time, Forte has seen an increasing demand for clean beauty, a need she was inspired to meet when she realized that the marquee ingredients for a skin-care line were available from the organic farm at the brand's Sicilian property, Verdura Resort. She turned to Francesca Ferri, a pharmacologist at Trento's EffegiLab, to create Irene Forte Skincare, which focuses on botanicals like hibiscus seed-the source of her patented oligopeptide complex aimed at smoothing fine wrinkles. The line is made entirely in Italy with many edible ingredients, making it much like a Mediterranean diet for the skin. "And, just like the Mediterranean diet," says Forte, "we believe in skin health and longevity, not faddy, quick fixes." shen-beauty.com

title: James Taylor: We Feel an Entitlement to Never Feel Sad
summary: The singer-songwriter-and five other cultural luminaries-on feelings of loss: "I'm 71, and when you get older you lose more and more. Your accumulated memory and personal history are a huge compensation, but you have fewer people to share that with.". "My first successful song was 'Fire and Rain,' which starts with losing a friend to suicide. There's a cumulative emotional quality to it, a message that's useful to hear. Why do people sing the blues? It's because it helps to share it with other people and to expiate it-to have it out in front of you. What you always hope for as a songwriter is that your way of manifesting your emotions will be useful to other people. But, generally, we don't engage with things that are hard. In modern culture, do we go too far in the direction of never doing anything that's unpleasant? It's almost like we're entitled to not having negative feelings. I'm 71, and when you get older you lose more and more. Your accumulated memory and personal history are a huge compensation, but you have fewer people to share that with. Maybe cumulative loss is what old age is."

title: 5G Picks Up but Nokia Sees Stagnant Growth
summary: Finnish company is up against fierce competition over 5G deals. Nokia Corp. reported a rise in fourth-quarter profit but warned of flat demand for telecom equipment and rising competition for 5G deals in the year ahead.

title: Vaping Crackdown Is a Mixed Blessing for Tobacco
summary: Ban on mint and fruit-flavored e-cigarettes will ease pressure on sales of traditional smokes. But it also complicates tobacco companies' pitch to investors.. Stronger sales of cigarettes will be an unintended side effect of the crackdown on vaping in the U.S. That isn't entirely good news for tobacco companies.

title: Public Transit Hits a Speed Bump: Not Enough Drivers
summary: After pushing for growth, systems are now cutting service because of staffing shortages. DENVER-For more than a decade, Denver has been on a public-transit expansion spree that so far has added 66 miles of new rail lines, 18 miles of new bus routes and 43 new stations. But now the system is considering reversing course and cutting service because it can't find enough people to drive its buses and trains.

title: EU Deepens Antitrust Inquiry Into Facebook's Data Practices
summary: Authorities have sought documents related to allegations that company leveraged access to user data to stifle competition. European Union antitrust investigators have sought internal documents related to Facebook Inc.'s alleged efforts to identify and squash potential rivals, deepening authorities' preliminary probe into the social-media company, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Elizabeth Warren Vows to Unite Party. Some Democrats Doubt She Can.
summary: Some undecided voters say they aren't convinced she can garner widespread support from moderate-leaning Democrats. NASHUA, N.H.-Elizabeth Warren promised Iowans she could unite her party's liberal and centrist wings in the final days before her better-than-expected finish in the presidential caucuses. But many voters in this state remain skeptical the liberal stalwart could appeal to a wide range of Democrats.

title: Will Ferrell and Julia Louis-Dreyfus Talk Skiing, Sudoku
summary: The co-stars of 'Downhill' on traveling in Austria for the film, their favorite vacation spots and the most underrated destinations in America (hers involves a canoe). "WE HAD NEVER met before," said Julia Louis-Dreyfus of Will Ferrell, her co-star in the movie "Downhill," which opens on Feb. 14. "It's so bizarre, given the fact that we know so many of the same people, and our lives have had these sort of parallel tracks." The key parallel-that both are "Saturday Night Live" alumni-is known to any nerd with a funny bone. While she went on to make her biggest marks in TV as Elaine Benes in "Seinfeld," and Selina Meyer in "Veep," he took to film, as the lead in "Anchorman" and "Elf," among others. In "Downhill," a remake of the 2014 Swedish black comedy "Force Majeure," Mr. Ferrell and Ms. Louis-Dreyfus go a shade darker, playing a married couple engulfed in strife on a family ski vacation in the Austrian Alps. Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, who was also a producer of the film, said she was drawn to the project because of the enormous conflict at the heart of the narrative. "When emotions are unspoken and things unsaid, I think the comedy and the drama both get pretty juicy," she said. We talked with the co-stars about filming in the Austrian Alps, where they travel off-camera and the items they keep stashed in their carry-ons.

title: ArcelorMittal Posts Earnings Beat Despite Tough Times for Steelmakers
summary: World's largest steelmaker predicts improved demand in the U.S. and Europe. ArcelorMittal SA shares jumped Thursday after the world's largest steelmaker beat earnings' expectations and predicted improved demand in the U.S. and Europe, following a tough year for the steel industry amid massive overcapacity and geopolitical uncertainty.

title: India's Central Bank Keeps Key Lending Rate Unchanged
summary: The Reserve Bank of India lowered its outlook on growth for the first half of the year. NEW DELHI-India's central bank left its key lending rate unchanged Thursday but made it easier for banks to offer auto and housing loans as it looked for ways to jumpstart growth without exacerbating inflation.

title: Big Business Is Driving America's Smaller Cities
summary: From restaurants to clinics, national chains offer most new jobs and services in small and medium markets.. title: Notable & Quotable: McConnell on Impeachment
summary: Washington Democrats think President Donald Trump committed a 'high crime or misdemeanor' the moment he defeated Secretary Clinton in the 2016 election.. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell before the final impeachment vote on Feb. 5:
